definition:
The Riemann integral of a function $f\colon I\to {\mathbf R}$
$$\int_I f(t)\, dt$$ is defined when $f$ is bounded and
$I=[a,b]\subset {\mathbf R}$ is a compact interval. If $I$ is any
interval of ${\mathbf R}$ and $f$ is bounded on every compact subset of
$I$ (for example $f$ is continuous), then we can define the concept of
*improper integral* of $f$ on $I$ by approximation of $I$ with compact
sets.

Let $I=(a,b)$ with $a\in[-\infty,+\infty)$ and $b\in(-\infty,+\infty]$
and let $f$ be a continuous function on $I$. Given $x,y\in I$ we know
that the function $f$ is Riemann integrable on $[a,b]$; hence we can
define the *improper integral of $f$ on $I$ as*
$$\int_I f(t)\, dt := \lim_{(x,y)\to(a,b),\ x>a, y<b} \int_x^y f(t)\, dt.$$

Notice that the limit is taken in two variables. In the case when $I$ is
compact this is the usual Riemann integral on $I=[a,b]$ (because the
integral function is continuous). So there is no ambiguity in using the
same simbol for improper integrals and usual Riemann integrals (but we
will see that there is an ambiguity when dealing with Lebesgue
integrals). Similarly, in the case when the interval $I$ is semi-open,
i.e. when $I=[a,b)$ with $a>-\infty$, the definition clearly reduces to
$$\int_I f(t)\, dt := \lim_{y\to b^-} \int_a^y f(t)\, dt$$ which is a
limit in one variable.

Notice also that an improper integral can be infinite or can possibly
not exist (even thought $f$ is continuous).

The definition may be extended to the case when $I$ is the union of a
finite number of intervals $I=I_1\cup\ldots I_N$ by summing up the
improper integrals on every interval:
$$\int_I f(t)\, dt := \sum_{k=1}^N \int_{I_k} f(t)\, dt.$$

In the case when $I={\mathbf R}$ (or more generally when $I$ has some
symmetry), one can define the *symmetric improper integral* as
$$\int_{{\mathbf R}} f(x)\, dx = \lim_{x\to+\infty} \int_{-x}^x f(t)\, dt.$$
This limit can exist in some cases when the *improper integral* (not
symmetric) fails to exist.

Examples
========

Given $I=(0,1]$, $f(t)=1/\sqrt t$ one has: $$\begin{aligned}
  \int_{(0,1]} \frac 1 {\sqrt t}\, dt 
&= \lim_{x\to 0^+}\int_x^1 \frac 1 {\sqrt t}\, dt \\
&= \lim_{x\to 0^+} [2t^\frac 1 2]_x^1 \\
&= \lim_{x\to 0^+} (2-2\sqrt x) = 2. \end{aligned}$$

Given $I=[1,+\infty)$, $f(t)=(\sin t)/t$ one can check that the improper
integral $\int_I f(t)\, dt$ exists and is finite but the improper
integral $\int_I |f(t)|\, dt$ is infinite. In particular this function
is not summable (in the sense of Lebesgue integrals) on the interval
$I$.

The function $f(t)=t/(1+t^2)$ has no improper integral in
$I={\mathbf R}$. But since $f(t)=-f(-t)$ one can easily check that the
symmetric integral is zero:
$$\lim_{x\to+\infty} \int_{-x}^x \frac{t}{1+t^2}\, dt =0.$$
